user_query: Can you clarify whether the claim "The 7.5% 10-year Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk threshold strategy for initiating statin therapy is less cost-effective than the 10% risk threshold strategy." is accurate or not? Build factual arguments about the claim.

Based on the information provided in the article, the claim that the 7.5% 10-year Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk threshold strategy for initiating statin therapy is less cost-effective than the 10% risk threshold strategy is accurate.
The article presents a microsimulation model of US adults aged 45 to 75 years, which estimates the cost-effectiveness of various 10-year ASCVD risk thresholds for initiating statin therapy. The results show that the current ASCVD threshold of 7.5% or higher (which is used in the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) cholesterol treatment guidelines) has an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of $37,000/quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) compared to a 10% or higher threshold. More lenient ASCVD thresholds of 4.0% or higher and 3.0% or higher have ICERs of $81,000/QALY and $140,000/QALY, respectively.
The article also finds that shifting from a 7.5% or higher ASCVD risk threshold to a 3.0% or higher ASCVD risk threshold would be associated with an additional 161,560 cardiovascular disease events averted. The results are sensitive to changes in the disutility associated with taking a pill daily, statin price, and the risk of statin-induced diabetes.
Based on these findings, it can be concluded that the 7.5% 10-year ASCVD risk threshold strategy is less cost-effective than the 10% risk threshold strategy, and more lenient ASCVD thresholds would be optimal using cost-effectiveness thresholds of $100,000/QALY (≥4.0% risk threshold) or $150,000/QALY (≥3.0% risk threshold).
It is important to note that the cost-effectiveness of different ASCVD risk thresholds may vary depending on the specific population being studied and the available treatment options.
